block.p: BMW'S new 3-liter twin-turbo engine has received top honors in the 2007 International Engine of the Year Awards.

The awards, organized by Engine Technology International, a trade publication, are selected by a panel of 62 automotive journalists from 30 countries. In addition to Engine of the Year, winners were named in several other categories.

BMW'S new 3-liter twin-turbo engine has received top honors in the 2007 International Engine of the Year Awards.

The awards, organized by Engine Technology International, a trade publication, are selected by a panel of 62 automotive journalists from 30 countries. In addition to Engine of the Year, winners were named in several other categories.

The twin turbo in-line 6 was also one of two BMW engines named to Ward's 10 Best Engines list for 2007. That list, in its 13th year, covers engines in vehicles costing no more than $54,000. Nissan's VQ twin-cam V-6 made the list for the 13th year.

Here are some of the International Engine of the Year winners for 2007: International Engine of the Year and Best New Engine, BMW 3-liter twin turbo (335i); Best Fuel Economy, Toyota 1.5-liter hybrid (Prius); Best Performance Engine, BMW 5-liter V-10 (M5, M6); 2 liters to 2.5 liters, BMW 2.5-liter (325, 525, X3, Z4); 2.5 liters to 3 liters: BMW 3-liter twin turbo (335i); 3 liters to 4 liters: Porsche 3.6-liter turbo (911); more than 4 liters: BMW 5-liter V-10 (M5, M6).

Here are the top 10 engines selected by Ward's: Audi 2-liter turbo 4 (A3); BMW 3-liter in-line 6 (Z4 3.0si); BMW 3-liter turbo in-line 6 (335i); DaimlerChrysler 3-liter turbodiesel V-6 (Mercedes-Benz E320 Bluetec) DaimlerChrysler 5.7-liter Hemi V-8 (Chrysler 300C); Ford Duratec 35 3.5-liter V-6 (Ford Edge); Ford 4.6-liter V-8 (Mustang GT); Mazda 2.3-liter turbo 4 (Mazdaspeed3); Nissan 3.5-liter V-6 (Infiniti G35); Toyota 3.5-liter V-6 (Lexus IS 350).
